newsitem.title: USA: NY company denies infringing on Reed Elsevier mark.
newsitem.headline: NY company denies infringing on Reed Elsevier mark.

text.p: The president of Lexis Service Corp on Friday denied that his company name infringes the LEXIS trademark owned by the Dutch-British publishing unit of Reed International Plc and Elsevier NV.

In papers filed Wednesday in the U.S. District Court in Delaware, Reed Elsevier Properties Inc sued Lexis Service alleging trademark infringement. Reed said it owned the LEXIS mark, which has been used since 1976 "with software allowing consumers to access computerized databases."

Lexis Services President Frank Villa told Reuters: "We're not infringing. We're a small manufacturing and service company -- not in their arena at all. The state of New York said (ours) was a viable corporate name."
Villa said the Bohemia, New York-based company services computer equipment for the U.S. Department of Defense.
Lexis Services began using the Lexis name in 1994 and "adopted a stylized font...similar" to that used by Reed, court papers say.

Reed wants a court order enjoining Lexis Service from using the trademark and ordering it to cancel its name registration with the state of New York and with the Internet. Reed also seeks unspecified damages of three times Lexis Service's profits.
